title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post:
In Constantinople, there were at least three distinct burial linens of Christ, one of them being our Shroud of Turin. I have evidence for this. I described it in this article in Polish http://ok.apologetyka.info/ateizm/ile-byo-pocien-pogrzebowych-jezusa-cz1,749.htm 
When I have time, I try to translate relevant fragments into English.
author: O.K.

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post: That would we wonderful. It is important. Thanks.
author: Dan

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post: Come on O.K. I want to see this evidence because if it convincing then you have to put everything aside and translate just the few relevant lines in English for us. After all, you know that we have been waiting for decades for concrete evidence and you will save IW and us a lot of time.
author: Louis

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post: I have sent it to Dan. But Louis, it is probably not what you expect. I don’t prove they were indeed true burial cloths of Jesus, I want just to show that there were three such alleged items in Constantinople.
author: O.K.

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post:
O.K. Thanks for the reply. What you mean to say is clear, it may not be concrete evidence but it does help narrow the search. More documentation would have been useful, and if it existed it was probably destroyed during the Fourth Crusade. Many of the documents Napoleon looted from the Vatican Archives are said to have been used by shopkeepers to wrap their goods. They probably obtained it from overloaded carts taking the material from Rome to Paris, with documents falling on the ground.
I wish you success in your research!
author: Louis

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post: Does the order of the list of relics mean anything? If the shroud was the most precious, why is it only ninth in the list, after a number of apparently less prestigious artefacts such as the reed he held instead of a sceptre?
author: Hugh Farey

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post:
Does the order of the list of relics mean anything? If the shroud was the most precious, why is it only ninth in the list, after a number of apparently less prestigious artefacts such as the reed he held instead of a sceptre?
Usually not, it is random. The top of the ranking is wood of the True Cross, which is often placed first, but here is 7th.
author: O.K.

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post: Good question, however since there were no editors around it is possible that the relics were listed as they came into his head.
author: Louis

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter
post: Good answers. So the most precious, most prominent, miraculously created actual image of their God was not the first thing, not even among the top five, that came into their heads. Interesting.
author: Hugh Farey

title: Drop the Alexios I Komnenos Letter

Good answers. So the most precious, most prominent, miraculously created actual image of their God was not the first thing, not even among the top five, that came into their heads. Interesting.
No, and I would say that this relic was in fact very problematic, perhaps even scandalous, for the Byzantines -at least from some perspective.
There are some reasons for this, which I will maybe explain later.
